p: Fifteen plus year ago I began my editorial marathon in earnest, with the primary goals of: (1) ensuring that clinical social work scholarship garners the respect it so richly deserves in the academy; (2) inculcating social work students into the robust theoretical and evidence-based world of clinical social work in an effort to debunk the myth that clinical social work only pertains and caters to wealthy clients in private practice; and, (3) having the CSWJ continue to serve as a vital resource for clinicians in agency-based and private practice settings. Toward these ends, I instituted a number of changes to build upon the fine works of my predecessor, the late Dr. Carolyn Saari. Specifically, I expanded the editorial board and consulting reviewer pool to include international social work luminaries, thereby establishing the CSWJ as a global entity, one more responsive to the needs of a cross-cultural readership. As part of that expansion, I continually sought reviewers with expertise in different evidence-based practice modalities, problem areas, theoretical perspectives, and vulnerable client populations to better tailor the review process to meet the didactic needs of the writers, some of whom were first time authors. To further enhance the quality and standing of the CSWJ, I employed a double-blind review process, increased the number of reviewers from two to three, and reduced the turnaround time from submission to decision.
